3. The SNMP Architecture -> 3.2. Element: In particular, a reference to an object as part of some version of the Internet-standard MIB does not resolve to any object that is not part of said version of the Internet-standard MIB, except in the case that the requested operation is get-next and the specified object name is lexicographically last among the names of all objects presented as part of said version of the Internet-Standard MIB.
4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elemen: The form of the GetResponse-PDU is identical to that of the GetRequest-PDU except for the indication of the PDU type.
In the ASN.1 language, GetResponse-PDU is defined as [2] IMPLICIT SEQUENCE containing request-id RequestID, error-status ErrorStatus, error-index ErrorIndex, and variable-bindings VarBindList.
The GetResponse-PDU is generated by a protocol entity only upon receipt of the GetRequest-PDU, GetNextRequest-PDU, or SetRequest-PDU, as described elsewhere in this document.

Before introducing the six PDU types of the protocol, it is appropriate to consider some of the ASN.1 constructs used frequently: request/response information includes RequestID as INTEGER, ErrorStatus as INTEGER with values noError(0), tooBig(1), noSuchName(2), badValue(3), readOnly(4), genErr(5), and ErrorIndex as INTEGER.
Variable bindings include VarBind as SEQUENCE of name ObjectName and value ObjectSyntax, and VarBindList as SEQUENCE OF VarBind.
By use of the RequestID, an SNMP application entity can correlate incoming responses with outstanding requests.
A VarBindList is a simple list of variable names and corresponding values.
4. Protocol Specification: A protocol entity receives messages at UDP port 161 on the host with which it is associated for all messages except for those which report traps (i.e., all messages except those which contain the Trap-PDU).
Messages which report traps should be received on UDP port 162 for further processing.
It is mandatory that all implementations of the SNMP support the five PDUs: GetRequest-PDU, GetNextRequest-PDU, GetResponse-PDU, SetRequest-PDU, and Trap-PDU.
The RFC1157-SNMP definitions begin with imports from RFC1155-SMI including ObjectName, ObjectSyntax, NetworkAddress, IpAddress, and TimeTicks.
The protocol data units (PDUs) include choices for get-request, get-next-request, get-response, set-request, and trap PDUs.
4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elemen: The Trap-PDU of type linkDown contains as the first element of its variable-bindings, the name and value of the ifIndex instance for the affected interface.
A linkUp(3) trap signifies that the sending protocol entity recognizes that one of the communication links represented in the agent's configuration has come up.
The Trap-PDU of type linkUp contains as the first element of its variable-bindings, the name and value of the ifIndex instance for the affected interface.

The form of the Trap-PDU is: Trap-PDU ::= [4] IMPLICIT SEQUENCE { enterprise OBJECT IDENTIFIER, agent-addr NetworkAddress, generic-trap INTEGER, specific-trap INTEGER, time-stamp TimeTicks, variable-bindings VarBindList } The Trap-PDU is generated by a protocol entity only at the request of the SNMP application entity.
The significance of the variable-bindings component of the Trap-PDU is implementation-specific.
Interpretations of the value of the generic-trap field are implementation-specific.
A enterpriseSpecific(6) trap signifies that the sending protocol entity recognizes that some enterprise-specific event has occurred.
The specific-trap field identifies the particular trap which occurred.
The Trap-PDU of type egpNeighborLoss contains as the first element of its variable-bindings, the name and value of the egpNeighAddr instance for the affected neighbor.
The form of the GetRequest-PDU is: GetRequest-PDU ::= [0] IMPLICIT SEQUENCE { request-id RequestID, error-status ErrorStatus, error-index ErrorIndex, variable-bindings VarBindList }.

Upon receipt of the GetRequest-PDU, the receiving protocol entity responds according to any applicable rule in the list below: (1) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the object's name does not exactly match the name of some object available for get operations in the relevant MIB view, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is noSuchName, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.

(2) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the object is an aggregate type (as defined in the SMI), then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is noSuchName, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.

(3) If the size of the GetResponse-PDU generated as described below would exceed a local limitation, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is tooBig, and the value of the error-index field is zero.

(4) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the value of the object cannot be retrieved for reasons not covered by any of the foregoing rules, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is genErr and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.

If none of the foregoing rules apply, then the receiving protocol entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU such that, for each object named in the variable- bindings field of the received message, the corresponding component of the GetResponse-PDU represents the name and value of that variable.
The value of the error-status field of the GetResponse-PDU is noError and the value of the error-index field is zero.
The value of the request-id field of the GetResponse-PDU is the same as the request-id field of the received message.

While implementations of the SNMP must be capable of generating the authenticationFailure trap, the SNMP implementations must also be capable of suppressing the emission of such traps via an implementation-specific mechanism.
The form of the GetNextRequest-PDU is identical to that of the GetRequest-PDU except for the indication of the PDU type.

Upon receipt of the GetNextRequest-PDU, the receiving protocol entity responds according to any applicable rule in the list below: (1) If, for any object name in the variable-bindings field, that name does not lexicographically precede the name of some object available for get operations in the relevant MIB view, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is noSuchName, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.

(2) If the size of the GetResponse-PDU generated as described below would exceed a local limitation, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is tooBig, and the value of the error-index field is zero.

(3) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the value of the lexicographical successor to the named object cannot be retrieved for reasons not covered by any of the foregoing rules, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is genErr and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.

If none of the foregoing rules apply, then the receiving protocol entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU such that, for each name in the variable-bindings field of the received message, the corresponding component of the GetResponse-PDU represents the name and value of that object whose name is the immediate successor to the name field value in the lexicographical ordering of all objects available for get operations in the relevant MIB view.
The value of the error-status field of the GetResponse-PDU is noError and the value of the error-index field is zero.
The value of the request-id field of the GetResponse-PDU is that of the received GetNextRequest-PDU message.
The form of the SetRequest-PDU is identical to that of the GetRequest-PDU except for the indication of the PDU type.

In the ASN.1 language, the SetRequest-PDU is defined as: SetRequest-PDU ::= [3] IMPLICIT SEQUENCE { request-id RequestID, error-status -- always 0 ErrorStatus, error-index -- always 0 ErrorIndex, variable-bindings VarBindList }.

Upon receipt of the SetRequest-PDU, the receiving entity responds according to any applicable rule in the list below: (1) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the object is not available for set operations in the relevant MIB view, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is noSuchName, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.

(2) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the contents of the value field does not, according to the ASN.1 language, manifest a type, length, and value that is consistent with that required for the variable, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is badValue, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name in the received message.

(3) If the size of the Get Response type message generated as described below would exceed a local limitation, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is tooBig, and the value of the error-index field is zero.

(4) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the value of the named object cannot be altered for reasons not covered by any of the foregoing rules, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is genErr and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.
If none of the foregoing rules apply, then for each object named in the variable-bindings field of the received message, the corresponding value is assigned to the variable.
Each variable assignment specified by the SetRequest-PDU should be effected as if simultaneously set with respect to all other assignments specified in the same message.

The receiving entity then sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form except that the value of the error-status field of the generated message is noError and the value of the error-index field is zero.
5. Definitions: RFC1157-SNMP DEFINITIONS begin with imports of ObjectName, ObjectSyntax, NetworkAddress, IpAddress, and TimeTicks from RFC1155-SMI.
Protocol data units are defined as a choice of get-request, get-next-request, get-response, set-request, and trap PDUs.
GetRequest-PDU is implicitly defined as PDU with tag [0], GetNextRequest-PDU as PDU with tag [1], GetResponse-PDU as PDU with tag [2], and SetRequest-PDU as PDU with tag [3].

PDU is defined as a sequence containing request-id as integer, error-status as integer with values noError(0), tooBig(1), noSuchName(2), badValue(3), readOnly(4), genErr(5), error-index as integer, and variable-bindings as VarBindList.

Trap-PDU is implicitly defined as a sequence with tag [4] containing enterprise as object identifier representing the type of object generating the trap, agent-addr as NetworkAddress representing the address of the object generating the trap, generic-trap as integer with values coldStart(0), warmStart(1), linkDown(2), linkUp(3), authenticationFailure(4), egpNeighborLoss(5), enterpriseSpecific(6), specific-trap as integer representing specific code present even if generic-trap is not enterpriseSpecific, time-stamp as TimeTicks representing time elapsed between the last reinitialization of the network entity and trap generation, and variable-bindings as VarBindList containing interesting information.
Variable bindings are defined with VarBind as a sequence containing name as ObjectName and value as ObjectSyntax, and VarBindList as a sequence of VarBind.
